basics.name: Stijn Koopal MSc.
basics.label: Independent Full Stack Software Craftsman
basics.summary:
I'm an experienced software enthusiast with hands-on experience in various languages, frameworks and platforms. Highly analytical in nature, with good communication skills. A supportive and enthusiastic team player that thinks highly of quality, but can be pragmatic if required. I tend to use the simplest solution best fit for the situation, keeping in mind the full architectural context of the application.

The thought of a fast, highly scalable and decoupled service architecture makes me happy, as does an elegant implementation. A very well-designed and maintainable frontend is key. I mostly enjoy working in a team, and building an awesome application together is very important to me.

The beautiful city of Utrecht is my home, and I tend to socialize there with friends a lot. I enjoy being outside, especially when exercising.

Interested? Drop me a line!
basics.shortSummary: Experienced full stack software engineer (JVM languages, Golang, React/Angular) with an agile mindset. Apt experience with Cloud and CI/CD, focusing on quality and architectural simplicity. Whatever it takes to provide customer value.

work.summary: DHL Parcel is increasing their market position by optimizing the receiver experience. Am helping out with integrating new parties, expanding the app and facilitating more fine-grained estimations and interactions with parcels

Graph driven insights are the future of data analytics. Knights enables companies to access untapped insights by unifying their complex data into a simple yet powerful, centralised knowledge store. Bootstrapped the UI that visualizes data.

ZorgDomein is a platform that connects healthcare professionals to healthcare providers. Was the team lead of an agile team focussed on the supplier side of the platform. Besides building new functionality, was part of the solution design for several major features. Also, helped getting the CI/CD pipeline to the next level.
highlights: Optimize buildstreet, resulting in ease of development
Performance improvements on Angular frontend, greatly improved experience
Implementation Covid-19 reporting
Proving value to customers using state-of-the-art tech
JAM stack: NextJS (React) with EmotionJS, HTML5/CSS3, Netlify
keywords: JAM stack: NextJS (React) with EmotionJS, HTML5/CSS3, Netlify

work.summary: The Floriday platform connects growers to retail. Was part of an agile team responsible for the sales and fulfillment side of a new platform. Besides building functionality in different Kotlin and Java services, helped getting the platform to a new architectural level using services from AWS.
highlights: Optimizing API management
Improving on CI/CD strategy
Rapid increase in growers connected
Kotlin, Java 11, Axon Framework, CQRS/ES, AWS, Spring Boot

work.summary: Supporting the Blockport team with development on a reactive crypto deposit solution using Kafka Streams and securely integration KYC into their application.
highlights: Scalable crypto deposits
Integrate KYC provider
Scala, Akka, Lagom, React, K8s, Golang, GCP

work.summary: Frontend lead on an internal web-app, it had to be rebuild from scratch using state-of-the-art Polymer 3 and Redux. On the backend, integrating LDAP and optimizing CI/CD infrastructure (Openshift, Gitlab) and improving data pipelines (Spark).
highlights: Complete overhaul of Polymer frontend to a very scalable (in terms of development) app
Connecting users to the Domino app
Knowledge sharing of state-of-the-art frontends
Polymer, Scala, Spark, Docker, Openshift, Gitlab CI

work.summary: Full-stack developer on a scrum team developing a model driven architecture (POC). Building on Java EE services and Angular frontends. Last few months part time Scrum master in a scrum of scrums setup.
highlights: Scrum master in a scrum of scrums setup
Generating application code for business flows and models
Java 8, JEE2, JBPM, Jenkins 2, Docker, AngularJS, Cucumber

work.summary: A project massively pressurized by time, initially was a backend developer (JBoss Fuse). Eventually responsible for the team as team lead.
highlights: Connected new platform to a legacy backend
Coaching of 2 juniors
Java 8, JBoss Fuse, JBoss EAP

work.summary: Lead on implementing a POC to setup Analytics within Malmberg: a solution based on Hadoop. Also, part of a scrum team that implemented shared components using Vert.x
highlights: Connecting data of over 10 applications
Building a support library on Vert.x that other projects could use to expose analytics
Hadoop, Java 8, Vert.x

work.summary: Functional Application Engineer maintaining and improving a legacy Java backend + UI. With weekly on-call duties.
Technical consultant focusing on customer-value, using bleeding edge technology

Scala, Akka, React, Polymer, Spark, Kotlin, Lagom, Golang, Axon Framework

publications.name: An Experimental Evaluation of Various Approximate Watershed Algorithms on Triangulated Terrains
publications.description: Modelling how water flows on landscapes in order to predict floods and other environmental phenomena, has always been of major importance in hydrology and ecological sciences. Today, flow modelling on landscapes is performed in a computer-based environment using digital representations of real-world terrains. One of the most popular digital terrain representations are the so-called Triangulated Irregular Networks (TINs) which are piecewise linear surfaces that consist of triangles. A natural way to model water flow on a surface is to assume that, at any point on the surface, water follows the direction of steepest descent (DSD). However, even this simple flow model has been proven computationally infeasible when applied on TINs. On the other hand, there exist many methods that compute flow paths on TINs approximately, that is without following strictly the DSD on the surface. Such methods do not suffer from the computational problems of the exact flow model. However, flow structures that are produced using these methods may provide a poor approximation of the structures that would be generated by the exact flow model. In this thesis we present various approximate algorithms for computing an important type of flow structure on TINs, namely watersheds. We evaluate these algorithms both in terms of efficiency and approximation quality in comparison to the exact flow model. We consider two different categories of methods; the first category involves methods that use exact arithmetic, and they can introduce new vertices on the TIN with coordinates of possibly large bit-size. The methods of the second category can only perform computations that use floating-point numbers. Among other results, we show that a widely used method provides the least quality of approximation in practice. We introduce methods that present a very good quality of approximation. Furthermore, we show that some methods do well on mountainous terrain whereas others do better on nearly flat terrains.
